Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, my whistle hanging loosely around my neck, the sound of laughter and splashing echoing in the humid air. My phone buzzed in my pocket—another message from my brother, reminding me that the family was waiting for me to join the holiday celebration at home. Mom had made my favorite dish, and everyone expected me to be there, to laugh, to share stories, to be a good sister. But as I glanced back at the water, I noticed a group of kids slipping into the shallow end, unsupervised, their parents distracted by their own conversations. My supervisor had drilled it into us: safety first, always. I was responsible for every person in that pool. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my family’s warm expectations pulling me one way, my duty as a lifeguard anchoring me to the poolside. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where I was needed most, torn between the call of home and the responsibility in front of me.
